awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of a scanless RADAR (RAdio Detection And Ranging) technology. This scanless sensor has the potential to possibly integrate large areas, perform faster scanning, focus on objects longer during tracking (especially in the near field), and image with a multi-frequency system without the need for a moving system. The ability to have multiple frequencies incorporated could be useful to maintain the ability to image in degraded environments without compromising high resolution. This innovation is expected to serve as a possible platform technology and could provide enhanced sensing capabilities for markets including autonomous vehicles, and medical devices for rural areas.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a novel remote sensing technique that leverages the benefits of both RADAR (RAdio Detection And Ranging) and LIDAR (Light Detection and Ranging). It provides a technology that could provide a wide field of view, without the need for a moving platform, at comparable resolutions to the current most advanced RADAR techniques. Current solutions for high-resolution imaging include digital beamforming and LIDAR. While digital beamforming can yield high-resolution scans, it requires multiple pulses to scan an entire scene.  Multiple sweeps of the scene of interest are required for digital beamforming as narrow directed beams must be used to get enhanced resolution. Digital beamforming contains a blind spot close to the RADAR (i.e., in the near field) due to certain assumptions that are made in its signal processing. LIDAR, which uses light waves instead of radio waves, delivers high resolution due to its small wavelength; however, these small wavelengths do not propagate through environments as well as radio waves and thus perform poorly in atmospheric conditions such as rain and fog. The proposed technology seeks to potentially process waves of any wavelength simultaneously and presents a needed solution for the integration of data obtained from different sensor types (e.g., RADAR, LIDAR, and SONAR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF I-Corps Teams project allowed Solopulse remote sensing technology to test its commercial viability in three separate sensing markets in telecommunications, medical imaging, and autonomous driving in the automotive space. In the first two weeks the team selected telecommunications and autonomous driving to pursue customer discovery in during the program as medical imaging devices have historically required 10–20-year development cycles as this space is most regulated, relative to the other two potential markets. During the I-Corps program, our team conducted 120 customer discovery interviews in the Autonomous Vehicle (AV)/ Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) and telecommunications industries. This included in person interviews at Future Tech in Atlanta, GA, where we met with the founder of the company who had experience addressing and integrating into numerous access points within the telecommunications industry. The team also attended climate week in New York City, NY to investigate the climate angle we had in reducing the hardware required and power needs of the telecommunications industry. These interviews were instrumental in identifying who our target customers are and what their needs and pain points are. 

By the end of the program the team decided to pursue ADAS, a subset of the initial AV/ADAS market we targeted coming into the program, as an initial beachhead market. The decision came down to two major finding, made during the NSF I-Corps Team project. The first of these was that the autonomous driving market saw a major hit while the team was in the program. This market stunting occurred due to a number of factors that were unrelated to sensor, and more specific, radar technology. A few of the major ones include heavy regulatory constraints in addition to issues with public acceptance of the technology. Thus, this detracted the Solopulse team from pursuing this market further. The second major finding was the trend in the telecommunication market that was occurring towards the implementation of Radio Access Networks (RAN). These RAN networks are built to be open source and enable testing, validation, and implementation to be streamlined for software solutions like Solopulse. However, these RAN networks have a three-to-five-time horizon before they are implemented. Thus, with the team realizing that the automotive market actually segments into AV systems and ADAS. While the AV market was stunted at the time of the teams participation in the I-Corps Team program the ADAS market has large pain points which Solopulse is able to address. 

Following the I-Corps program a startup was formed, SoloPulse Corp. SoloPulse Corp. has successfully licensed the core SoloPulse technology from Georgia Tech and raised venture capiral. Our teans project vision is to be a dual-use radar company that provides innovative software solutions that can be integrated into existing radar hardware, enhancing their capabilities, and enabling them to meet the demands of modern defense and civilian applications. Our software solution provides unmatched value propositions in resolution, latency, and power, enabling radar systems to achieve higher resolution images with minimal delay while consuming less power. We plan to design our software to enable simple and quick integration into existing radar systems, making the upgrade process seamless and cost-effective. With our software solution we plan to enhance the performance and functionality of existing radar systems, ensuring that they remain relevant and effective in the face of evolving threats and challenges. Our vision is to be a leading provider of software solutions that bring advanced radar capabilities to existing hardware, enabling our clients to stay ahead of the curve and achieve their mission objectives with confidence.
